contentrichtext.text: {{nihongo|'''Yasumasa Kanada'''|金田 康正|Kanada Yasumasa|extra=born 1949}} is a [[Japan]]ese [[mathematician]] most known for his numerous world records over the past three decades for calculating digits of [[pi|{{pi}}]]. He has set the record 11 of the past 21 times. Kanada is a professor in the Department of Information Science at the [[University of Tokyo]] in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]]. From 2002 until 2009, Kanada held the world record calculating the number of digits in the decimal expansion of pi – exactly 1.2411 trillion digits. The calculation took more than 600 hours on 64 nodes of a [[HITACHI SR8000/MPP]] [[supercomputer]].
